trans-unit.source: Media Services REST API overview | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Media Services REST API overview | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Media Services is a service that accepts OData-based HTTP requests and can respond back in verbose JSON or atom+pub.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Media Services is a service that accepts OData-based HTTP requests and can respond back in verbose JSON or atom+pub.

trans-unit.source: Because Media Services conforms to Azure design guidelines, there is a set of required HTTP headers that each client must use when connecting to Media Services, as well as a set of optional headers that can be used.
trans-unit.target: Because Media Services conforms to Azure design guidelines, there is a set of required HTTP headers that each client must use when connecting to Media Services, as well as a set of optional headers that can be used.

trans-unit.source: The following sections describe the headers and HTTP verbs you can use when creating requests and receiving responses from Media Services.
trans-unit.target: The following sections describe the headers and HTTP verbs you can use when creating requests and receiving responses from Media Services.

trans-unit.source: For every call you make into Media Services, there is a set of required headers you must include in your request and also a set of optional headers you may want to include.
trans-unit.target: For every call you make into Media Services, there is a set of required headers you must include in your request and also a set of optional headers you may want to include.

trans-unit.source: The following table lists the required headers:
trans-unit.target: The following table lists the required headers:

trans-unit.source: Bearer is the only accepted authorization mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Bearer is the only accepted authorization mechanism.

trans-unit.source: The value must also include the access token provided by ACS.
trans-unit.target: The value must also include the access token provided by ACS.

trans-unit.source: Because Media Services uses OData to expose its underlying asset metadata repository through REST APIs, the DataServiceVersion and MaxDataServiceVersion headers should be included in any request; however, if they are not, then currently Media Services assumes the DataServiceVersion value in use is 3.0.
trans-unit.target: Because Media Services uses OData to expose its underlying asset metadata repository through REST APIs, the DataServiceVersion and MaxDataServiceVersion headers should be included in any request; however, if they are not, then currently Media Services assumes the DataServiceVersion value in use is 3.0.

trans-unit.source: The following is a set of optional headers:
trans-unit.target: The following is a set of optional headers:

trans-unit.source:
The requested content type for the response such as the following:

-application/json;odata=verbose

- application/atom+xml

Responses may have a different content type, such as a blob fetch, where a successful response will contain the blob stream as the payload.
trans-unit.target:
The requested content type for the response such as the following:

-application/json;odata=verbose

- application/atom+xml

Responses may have a different content type, such as a blob fetch, where a successful response will contain the blob stream as the payload.

trans-unit.source: GZIP and DEFLATE encoding, when applicable.
trans-unit.target: GZIP and DEFLATE encoding, when applicable.

trans-unit.source: Note: For large resources, Media Services may ignore this header and return noncompressed data.
trans-unit.target: Note: For large resources, Media Services may ignore this header and return noncompressed data.

trans-unit.source: Specifies the preferred language for the response.
trans-unit.target: Specifies the preferred language for the response.

trans-unit.source: Allows clients or firewalls that do not support HTTP methods like PUT or DELETE to use these methods, tunneled via a GET call.
trans-unit.target: Allows clients or firewalls that do not support HTTP methods like PUT or DELETE to use these methods, tunneled via a GET call.

trans-unit.source: Content type of the request body in PUT or POST requests.
trans-unit.target: Content type of the request body in PUT or POST requests.

trans-unit.source:
A caller-defined value that identifies the given request. If specified, this value will be included in the response message as a way to map the request.

Important

Values should be capped at 2096b (2k).
trans-unit.target:
A caller-defined value that identifies the given request. If specified, this value will be included in the response message as a way to map the request.

Important

Values should be capped at 2096b (2k).

trans-unit.source: The following is a set of headers that may be returned to you depending on the resource you were requesting and the action you intended to perform.
trans-unit.target: The following is a set of headers that may be returned to you depending on the resource you were requesting and the action you intended to perform.

trans-unit.source: A unique identifier for the current operation, service generated.
trans-unit.target: A unique identifier for the current operation, service generated.

trans-unit.source: An identifier specified by the caller in the original request, if present.
trans-unit.target: An identifier specified by the caller in the original request, if present.

trans-unit.source: The date that the request was processed.
trans-unit.target: The date that the request was processed.

trans-unit.source: The content type of the response body.
trans-unit.target: The content type of the response body.

trans-unit.source: The following is a complete list of HTTP verbs that can be used when making HTTP requests:
trans-unit.target: The following is a complete list of HTTP verbs that can be used when making HTTP requests:

trans-unit.source: Returns the current value of an object.
trans-unit.target: Returns the current value of an object.

trans-unit.source: Creates an object based on the data provided, or submits a command.
trans-unit.target: Creates an object based on the data provided, or submits a command.

trans-unit.source: Replaces an object, or creates a named object (when applicable).
trans-unit.target: Replaces an object, or creates a named object (when applicable).

trans-unit.source: Updates an existing object with named property changes.
trans-unit.target: Updates an existing object with named property changes.

trans-unit.source: Returns metadata of an object for a GET response.
trans-unit.target: Returns metadata of an object for a GET response.

trans-unit.source: To make Media Services entities more discoverable, the $metadata operation can be used.
trans-unit.target: To make Media Services entities more discoverable, the $metadata operation can be used.

trans-unit.source: It allows you to retrieve all valid entity types, entity properties, associations, functions, actions, and so on.
trans-unit.target: It allows you to retrieve all valid entity types, entity properties, associations, functions, actions, and so on.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to construct the URI: https://media.windows.net/API/$metadata.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to construct the URI: https://media.windows.net/API/$metadata.

trans-unit.source: You should append "?api-version=2.x" to the end of the URI if you want to view the metadata in a browser, or do not include the x-ms-version header in your request.
trans-unit.target: You should append "?api-version=2.x" to the end of the URI if you want to view the metadata in a browser, or do not include the x-ms-version header in your request.
